w3Qk4EC_ntNwvrYkZ2CCnA.text: heard so many rave reviews of this place, but sadly very disappointed.to be fair, the pizza is nice (but not amazing) but the choice of a margherita or anchovy/caper pizza for non pork-eating diners isn't really the best.the lemonade is also totally vile water and margherita. yum :(

LtzQm0CKOwoeTtPvS8aT_A.text: Outstanding thin crust pizzas, friendly and speedy service, prices reasonable (for London). I will return.

0wljE55p6lU_3GRFhd1U7A.text: INCREDIBLE pizzas, great atmosphere, ok-ish service, cheap prices for London. One thing - Wine was warm and served in a water glass. Wine should be served in a wine glass. Other than that probably the best pizza i've had in England.

_HAfvdOlhVDjcSBQTom6Gw.text: Great service, great food. I had a pizza I didn't really like (the toppings, my own fault) and was changed instantly by a very charming sicilian girl. Best pizza place I've been in a while n

BK9d8HIaaOMoNWXI9vKfAg.text: such good pizza, such good value for money. i hope they never change that, it's so delightful going somewhere for properly good food, and not feeling guilty or ripped off by the amount you are being charged - after all, simple pizzas like this are NOT expensive to make, so it is definitely refreshing to see a mark up that isn't insane. saying that, i do appreciate that the ingredients they use are high quality, so the cost of producing it will be higher.franco manco keeps their menu simple, so what they do, they do extremely well. they offer about 6 or 7 standard pizzas, plus one veg special and one meat special. i went here for lunch today with my boyfriend and a friend, and we were all very happy with our choices! i had the veg special which had artichokes, cherry tomatoes, and lots of yummy cheese. the sourdough base is amazing and the pizzas are so filling and mmm good! i am definitely a fan, and for £7.50, amazing! the plain margarita pizzas start somewhere around the £4.50 mark, so this really can be a very cheap dinner out. the service in this particular outpost was really good, really attentive and friendly, and the atmosphere inside was nice. i have never made it to the original franca manco in brixton, despite being in that area quite frequently, but i have now eaten here and at the franca manco in westfield, and each time i leave very, very happy!

ar_k4wZtTSsYuBZ8AGqxdg.text: Quick service - tasty pizza - great atmosphere. Only picked up a takewawy here, but if we'd been sticking around, I'd have been very happy to stay here for the evening. Lively and full of smiling faces.

BlXS2NmJbSxxnJOlC08BwA.text: Nice place for pizzas and salads. The concept is pretty simple and works well. The salads are fine, nothing incredibly original but a good side to their execellent pizzas. Service is friendly and the pizzas come fast. The atmosphere is relaxed and not pretentious like too many places in London. Pizza portions are large and should be shared so that you try many different ones. Deserts are not worth the money, there and are a let down, so skip desert and have an ice cream somewhere else in Chiswick. We'll definitly go back. See you there!

pVqGXfpYMT5Og_-T5LcEXw.text: This place is the business. A tenner will buy you a tumbler of wine and a big round seriously doughy dinner. I think the theme is speed here, I've never been served so quickly, they practically flung it across the restaurant like a big formaggio frisbee. Hands down the best pizza in London, served to you by real-life sicillian mobsters.

ZIduPb_uV2xts9pN3rTMHA.text: This is the best pizzeria in West London by a country mile and it is super good value. The sourdough base is legendary and the ingredients are top quality. For example take the artichokes: they are neither swimming in oil nor burnt to the core, but simply char-grilled and retain their delicious earthiness. The decor is simple because the star of the show is the food and it's the perfect place for a joyous dinner with friends. By the way the wines are much better now, thanks for asking!

xLYKLXwn3nJL_8TZjm_D4w.text: The best thing about Franco Manca is the value for money. A lot of the cafes and restaurants in Chiswick are a tad expensive for a weekly lunch trip so FM stands out. I had an organic lemonade (very tasty) and a delicious but simple pizza for 6.95 (quite big as well). Lots of flavour and a nice gooey but cripsy on the outside base. Comfortably under a tenner. Plus they have outside seating for a nice sunny day.

5ffaWFLrymrd1czL7oIA9g.text: West London pizza lovers rejoice! No longer simply a South London institution, Brixton's foodie favoured pizzeria - Franco Manca - has opened a second branch in villagey Chiswick. And if my experience at their launch party (londonist.com/2010/02/ne…) is at all representative of what diners can expect, W4 residents and those inclined to travel a bit for quality nosh are in for a treat!The secret to Franco Manca's success is its wood burning oven-baked, low rising sourdough crust. Chiswick and FM's original pizzeria in Brixton are a bit far afield for me, but I'm up for the journey. It's definitely worth it!

FooyXtzLUoIwmzvDgCTJUA.text: Really decent sourdough pizzas for the right prices. Not a huge selection, but totally worth it. The starters are especially good value. We ordered garlic bread, which is as big as a pizza in its own right.  Friendly waitstaff took down our mobile number even though we hadn't booked a table, and directed us to the nearby Roebuck. Definitely check this place out!

hX-e7532EkPrDtZTIkBmXA.text: Franco Manca in Chiswick - Pics at The London Foodie(thelondonfoodie.co.uk ) Dr G and I recently went to the newly opened branch of Franco Manca in Chiswick with fellow food blogger Su-Lin of Tamarind & Thyme. Unlike the Brixton joint, the Chiswick branch is a real restaurant  it feels modern and casual with a massive mosaic-tiled, wood-burning oven dominating its entrance. I liked the simplicity and understated elegance of the décor, the long communal tables, and the uncluttered and airy space. Much has been said about Franco Manca, its slow-rising sourdough pizza base (minimum 20 hours), and the organic Italian or locally sourced ingredients (see Su-Lin's great review on Tamarind & Thyme). I was however still impressed to find how delicious their pizza dough was  this was for me the main event regarding Franco Manca. The dough was elastic with a deliciously chewy, dense consistency like good quality sourdough bread. The crust had been beautifully charred giving a woody, smoky flavour to the dough. Also impressive was how affordable Franco Manca's pizzas were, priced between £4.50 and£6.90. This is much better value than similar Neapolitan style pizzerias like Rossopomodoro or Pizza East. We shared three of the starters Aubergine alla Parmegiana, Garlic Pizza Bread and Fresh Buffalo Mozzarella. The aubergine was beautifully made, and so was the rather large garlic sourdough bread. The buffalo mozzarella was, in my opinion, not as sensational as the one I tried at Rossopomodoro, and the addition of tomato sauce to the mozzarella overpowered its delicate flavour. As for the pizza, Su-Lin and I went for Meat Special @ £6.90 (wild mushrooms, wild boar, smoked buffalo mozzarella). This was very good, with a generous topping of mozzarella and mushrooms. The wild boar salami was also a nice addition. The pizza base was sensational, and the fact that it was a white pizza (with no tomato sauce) did not detract from the overall experience. Dr G went for a Number 5 @ £6.80 (tomato, cured organic chorizo (dry and semi Dry), mozzarella). The tomato sauce tasted fresh and had probably been made on the premises. It was again a delicious pizza with authentic ingredients. We shared a bottle of organic Dolcetto £9.20, this was a simple and rustic wine and although well priced, it was disappointingly of not very good quality. Su-Lin had a 250ml bottle of organic lemonade £1.80, and we both wished we had ordered the same. Cost: around £45 (£15 per person) including a bottle of wine & service. Likes: sensational sourdough base, good quality & authentic ingredients, very affordable prices, and free filtered water. Dislikes: limited wine choices (only one red and one white option). Verdict: One of the best pizzerias in London, serving excellent sourdough pizza base at very affordable prices. It may lack the glamour of Pizza East or Rossopomodoro's central location but their pizzas are second to none and will set you back significantly less. Highly recommended. *Update* - Since writing this post, I heard from Giuseppe M. of Franco Manca, this is what he wrote: Many thanks for you kind comments. Since your visit we have changed the house wine (which was there only temporarely) and have replaced with an organic wine. This makes possibly the best value for money in London. The wine list also includes 5 reds and 3 whites now. We work with an organic farm in Italy and this is the new outcome. I sometimes hear from restaurants I review but I'd never had such positive response, thanks Giuseppe! The London Foodie on 2nd March 2010.

zkbm_QpZcGDem1PRSpAi1g.text: Oh yeah. TOTALLY the best Pizza in London. I know there is a lot of Hype around this place, and we are a sceptical people, us Yelpers, but this place is TOTALLY BOMB.I don't like meat, but for those of you who dig on swine, the meat pizza was PORKTASTIC it has pepperoni, chorizo.. prosciutto... other meats that I can't remember. I think the crust was my favorite part. I wanted to roll my pizza up into a ball and make a pillow on it, and sleep on it everynight.There was an instant silence that fell over the table once we had all finished the meal. We all had a moment of silence for the Pizza's that we loved, and we mourned them and wished we had more pizza. but I honestly don't think i could have eaten anymore pizza. AND THE PRICE WAS AMAZING.DAMN YOU FOR BEING SO FAR AWAY. However, if you were closer, I would probably fantasize about a Pizza bed, and at £6 a pizza, I might be tempted to make my Pizza bed dream come true.

GWqMcvrjTm7wHXPuFT1m3w.text: At Franco Manca you can get great value for your money, especially in Chiswick. Their ingredients are fresh and very high quality, organic. Most dishes are simple, yet tasteful from my opinion. Service, on the other hand, could be better. If you're in Chiswick, pay the place a visit for a weekday lunch.

r_Tsbvo2Z025xuS1zvxxrg.text: Genuine mystery to me why people go on about Franco Manca so much. We have only been once but had a very average pizza  yes it was was cheap but not a patch on Zizzi's up the road so maybe it's because we aren't looking for that.Also the place was packed out heaving with kids to the point where it was too intrusive if you're not in that demographic. There was nothing terrible about it, but nothing great either and with all the choice in Chiswick it's so far been an easy decision to go elsewhere ever since..

D9hQ6Pf3HpiaKd6-yAKBRg.text: I love the pizza here... so far the best I had in London. I was desperate to find a truly Italian pizza in London and a friend suggested this one. The decor is good and we never had problems getting a table on Sundays. The pizza is very good, a bit different from how they do it in the part of Italy I came from but I loved it anyways. One star missing for the very short list of toppings available. Definitely recommended.

UnFE2M2xnfDUcYujtmIC5w.text: After all the hype, I have to admit I was a bit disappointed. I had a vegetarian pizza with different cheeses and courgettes which was not amazing, and noticeably lacked any tomato base. The sourdough pizza is good, but it's more like soft bread and I like my pizza to have some crisp to it. Service was pretty good and we didn't have to wait, which was a nice surprise. Small house salad was really good, the house red wine, not so much. Apparently the 'meat special' pizza which someone else had at my table was better than mine, but even that wouldn't be called the best pizza in London.

bEWkb2N8hLd4C3xequ-ZbQ.text: I visited Franco Manca last night, what a pleasant experience it was. The pizzas were superb (mine was the meat special and my girlfriends was the vegetable equivalent), the service was excellent and the drinks were good.If you don't like superb classic Italian pizzas, then don't bother coming here, you're not going to like it! I used to work in Italy and I have eaten great pizzas from many of the mother countries superb pizzerias and I'm glad to say, Franco Manca hits the mark!There are only six pizzas to choose from, but if you ask nicely the friendly staff will let you take toppings from other pizzas to create your own special.It goes to show that really good pizzas don't have to cost the earth(prices range from about £6.50 to £7.50 per pizza).Bravo Franco!

_FQMR_vHib61oy6_MaMJjQ.text: Good pizza's and that blud but I dun know what the fuss is about. I've been talking like a bumbaclart yoot ever since I ate there last week. Need a greater selection of toppings for the mandem. 2/3 meat based toppings isn't enough.

7vqjb8K_z9HDZeVwcmuoYQ.text: It's a really nice restaurant but i definitely woldn't come back!, Quality of food horrible and the service it doesn't exist in that place It's shame because i was a regular customer and they just changed my opinion about it.

hSQSnixGIOw6fXScmSBFLg.text: Franco Manca was an excellent addition in this posh Chiswick neighbourhood, where you can get anything from a pizza / burger to a Michelin star restaurant dinner.One of the few unpretentious places in London where you can get a decent pizza at a reasonable price ( most expensive £ 7.50 ), especially in this area. The food is good - even if the choice is a bit limited and always the same - but it is fresh and tasty.Wine served in water glass is not top, but the homemade lemonade is good, sometimes a little too sweet.If you want a "quick" dinner on a budget, this is the place to go... and so we will go back again...

xSCEJ3cErhaqRnWXfRRnow.text: The best pizza I have eaten on this side of the Atlantic. Really tasty, fast service and really good value. Two pizzas, one beer, one (awesome) lemonade and a mixed salad for £20 including a tip. My new favourite in Chiswick.

tO0_d8IFxlHs3Hcr534coQ.text: A bit disappointed. Restaurant looks great and staff is very friendly but we made the mistake of going there a Friday night. Extremely noisy, uncomfortable and they only serve local, organic wines that were not good. Sorry guys

07n23dZulRs3_yg11ysykw.text: Chiswick is close to my new temporary hood in Hammersmith, and home to many fond memories spanning back to 2006. I couldn't step foot in W4 for until 2008, however Saturday night was another welcome return to the High Road as I hit the new boy to the Brixton ancestral pizzeria. The interior was a little naff I must say, however it was the modestly priced food and broad selection of recommendations that compelled me to visit. The slow-rising sourdough taking a mere 20 hours is the unique selling point. The veggie-friendly buffalo ricotta (I know, I thought it was mozzarella too but then again I'm a bad Italian) loaded with crisp zucchini made me very happy. I'd only comment on the house white being served in a tumbler, which made me grimace on arrival, but nonetheless went down a treat. A victory for value and taste.

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom

s-C29AC-ZUFhpYkY1eB3zw.text: Are you kidding me?! The best sourdough pizza ever, for about £6? You're having a laugh! If you don't like this you don't like real pizza. End of. The sides are very tasty but a bit small and pricey, but the pizzas are so cheap you don't care!

xpmru2grS15BhvUOeCr80w.text: Friendly staff, delicious and very reasonably priced pizza, fast service - no complaints! A lovely meal!

KqUCbOPn5tB3z9hBRebcsw.text: Franco Manca doesn't seem like it should exist.It is much too affordable for the absolutely amazing pizza pie you get. Around 5 pounds for easily the best pizza in all London. This Chiswick location gets the added plus(or minus for some) in that it seems more like a full sit down restaurant, rather than a quirky tasty add on to Brixton Market.Alan's 5 Slices Review SystemI've had many but I'll review my favorite. Tomato, Cured Organic Chorizo (Dry & Semi-Dry) and Mozzarella+1 (1/1) Crust- One of the best crusts of ANY pizza place I've been to, Italy and New York included. They use a very unique sourdough crust that is so soft and a bit doughie. Tastes like perfectly baked bread.+.9 (1.9/2) Sauce- Very simple sauce of what tastes of fresh tomatoes turned into sauce and a sprig of basil. What makes it great is how fresh it is how the flavor that comes from such simple ingredients.+1 (2.9/3) Cheese- Love the cheese. Nice and flavorful buffalo mozzarella. Always tastes so fresh. Not the weepy, waterykind, this kind keeps its flavor intact and lets the sauce do its own thing.+.8 (3.7/4) Toppings- Two very nice types of chorizo. One a flatter and one thicker. They flatter one looked a bit like salami or pepperoni, but had a classic chroizo taste. The thicker one was even more flavorful and juicy. Both extremely flavorful and authentic. +.8 (4.5/5) Atmosphere/Service/Price- The Chiswick is a much different atmosphere than the Brixton counterpart. It seems like a nice modern Italian sit down restaurant, while still keeping the great value. It is an astoundingly good deal for any of the pizzas, but the classic Margarita is only 5.50. If you can find a better deal in the ridiculously overpriced city of London, please let me know.Final Score:Franco Manca - 4.5 slices out of 5Best pizza place in London, probably the UK and in my top 10 of all time.

-uqNo98DHHg3NIzXuBtpoA.text: Who did say London was expensive? This place is amazing, the Napolitan spirits in Ghiswick, just moved in this area and already have been few times to this place to eat in or take away. They prepared Healthy-Tasty pizza with a secret recipe for them crust, and the cherry on the tiramisu is the fair price (It has my record of the cheapest eating-out evening)! I definitaly recommand.Tips: For dessert ask for a scoop of vanilla ice cream with an expresso, just pour the expresso on the ice cream, yes it is heaven. Yummi.

X8NNlMars-sRsWFZ-rvmFg.text: It isn't the best pizza I've had. But it was good and the price is pretty reasonable. I ordered a number 5 with mozzarella, tomato sauce, basil, anchovies, and olives (no capers for me, thanks!). I was pretty hungry, and yes I finished it all on my own. I wish they had more choices though. Will probably be back again.

gUQWfCJSPc5GjZ6XwncSFw.text: Amazing pizza as it's made in Italy.  Haven't had a better one since I was in Rome!  Cheap as well, my new favourite place!

7l9vGPshETZDGg70FoLHTw.text: Good Neapolitan style pizza -- great if you like thin but soft crust. Quick service and very reasonably priced, but when they get busy the pizza sometimes comes out a little undercooked.

wEv8N0LB7QT34_aEKVObcg.text: I dunno. I was a bit disappointed, actually. Not because the pizza wasn't good; it was. But because the pizza wasn't amazing, which was what I was expecting of Franco Manca's reputation.The sourdough crust was wonderfully chewy and suitably tasty, but the pizza itself was, well, just a good, authentic-tasting pizza. Nothing mind-blowing or worth going out of my way for, certainly. Although, that being said, the prices are pretty amazing, so maybe it IS worth it. The best part of the meal though had to be the totally gluggable and inexpensive wine I got to go with it.

pp-TSNc-1jSCsjEqWpBZlQ.text: Oh, Franco Manca, how I dream about your pizza... why must you be only in the UK... you could show us New Yorkers a thing or two about pizza... yes I said it!I don't know where the people who weren't wowed by this place are eating pizza at. Seriously. The only pizza I've ever had that has even come CLOSE to being this good was in Naples- no surprise as Franco Manca uses Neopolitan flour- and Zero Otto Nove on Arthur Ave in the Bronx. And the only reason I liked that place was because it reminded me of Franco Manca!You CANNOT beat this place for value for money- especially in London where most restaurants act as though they are doing you a favor by ripping you off in price and serving you sub-standard food by waitresses who don't speak English.Franco Manca, I adore you and your pizza!!

c9O-P5ZT4YwJxF8to64lnQ.text: For me (and I'm italian) the best pizza in London.I'm a regular client of this restaurant in Chiswick and if I'm missing Italy this is the place to go for me. The service sometime is a little bit hit and miss and when the venue is packed they can mess up with the orders but you turn a blind eye on it as the pizza is always delicious and the ingredients are always fresh plus it's a very informal restaurant and not pretentious at all so there is no point to be so picky (that is referred to some comments I read about wine served in water glasses).I would rate it 5 stars but JUST because of the service I rate it 4.

zXvGQig_A1SASuQvL992Cg.text: Yes! Excellent gourmet pizza. This is hard to find in London (actually, I haven't done much searching, I'm just assuming). There's quite a long queue around the block, but come here for great food, nice ambience, and a very buzzing young person environment. The whole street is buzzing, actually.

UGOFp9miw88HTFuPHx2JBg.text: I used to live in Chiswick years ago when the high road was really boring and had nothing to offer apart from Pizza Express on one end of the scale and unaffordable nouvelle cuisine (this was the eighties after all ...) on the other extreme.Franco Manca is the latest surprise which forces me to reconsider my prejudices against this part of West London ...I went for a late dinner with an Italian friend the other day - she felt at home and I felt like being on holiday in Italy. All the staff are Italian and the food seems authentic, too. We also experienced some typically (!?) Italian chaos with partially missed orders and forgotten wine top-ups - but somehow this only added to the atmosphere.I like concise menues, and this one is just the right length - they also have changing specials, so you are unlikely to get bored. I also like restaurants which take pride in the origin of their produce, and Franco Manca ticks all the boxes.The sourdough pizzas were delicious (I like mine a bit crunchier, but I suppose this is the way it's meant to be) even if the toppings were a bit sparse. My friend asked for extra tomato sauce which was added without any hassle.I had a baked aubergine dish which was the perfect starter size - it was still sizzling when served.Meat eaters will probably be even more excited as there are loads of special types available.The wine list is lmited to a couple of organic varieties which are available in white or red. I like the fact they are served in tumblers rather than stemmed glasses - this goes with the general relaxed fell of the place.Meals in pizza joints tend to be over too quickly and most restaurants are in the fast food league as a result. I didn't feel rushed at Franco Manca, indeed we ordered another glass of wine to enjoy at one of the tables outside.

eC8QnMeEpgNhwCZdbxcEtw.text: Best pizza I have had in London and a great place for a cheap eat. Pizza is crisp, perfect thickness, and cheese/sauce combination. I always go for the pizza with anchovies and capers and I am never disappointed.

Rk2Yik-SHJed6vXkLw1ppQ.text: Believe the hype. My friend and I were on our 'Chiswick recce' trip and stumbled on this place completely by chance. I knew about the Brixton branch and had heard many, many people sing its praises, so we couldn't walk by the Chiswick branch without giving it a try. The pizzas are just wow. Yes, I'm using wow as an adjective. My prerogative. I went for pizza #6, the tomato, anchovy, caper, olive, garlic and mozzarella, with some fresh chili on top. It had a very good crust to pizza ratio (unlike Pizza East - boo! hiss!) and was just loaded full of flavour. I'm not a big crust eater, but I polished this bad boy off - it was soft, yet crusty, a nice balance. The pizza I went for could've been very overwhelming with all the strong ingredients, but it was just right, with a real balance of flavour. Worth the trip to Chiswick. True fact.

eLKhvNC8RrdrSfeuOeLgEA.text: This is a good local pizza joint, fresh ingredients and friendly service in an airy, roomy restaurant. It is not, however, in my opinion everything people crack it up to be. The dough is somewhat heavy and stodgy with the base on the thick side for what you'd expect and the sauce on the bland side. For superlative Neopolitan style pizza, you'll want to visit Santa Maria in Ealing Green. This is the best pizza you can possibly find in the city by a long shot. Gets kudos for being so reasonably priced though.

2ISK8ZfOcTdoUNsRH54FqA.text: best pizza in london!!! great staff, service and quality food at quality price. we always get free limoncello shots at the end as we know the staff well. always wonderful and attentive to our needs. just dont ask for 'prosciutto' as u will get ham not the raw stuff.

u2u_0tjfO_Tb_aRtIDokIA.text: Praised as the best pizza in London by a ridiculous amount of people, I had to try it out. Amazingly, the Brixton branch is only opened for lunch, so me and my trusty foodie friend gritted our teeth and took the district line (boo) to Turnham Green (oh, I mean Chiswick? My bad), where a new, evening branch has opened. After fairly skipping into the resturant in excitment, we perused the menu. We decided to order two pizzas, sharing half each. We went for their Meat special (Parma ham, rocket and mozzarella on tomato) along with menu no.6 (mozzarella and chorizo on tomato). After a 20 minutes wait our pizza's were placed on the table. A good size, slightly flopping over the edge. Lifting up mine (I had first go at the meat special), I noticed the base was so thin you could see the light shining through. The toppings were absolutely delicious. Rocket, Italian style ham and shavings of grana padano are my new topping selection to emulate, Flavorful, filling but not stodgy at all. I could have eaten the whole thing. But sadly, I had already promised to share half with my slow eating friend. Over she handed her chorizo pizza, as regretfully I watched my delicious meat special float away. The chorizo pizza was sadly affected by being a little cool. Thin pizza gets cold pretty quickly. Despite this, and the curiously limited amount of cheese on the base, you could still taste the awesome potential of a pizza topped with melt in the mouth, greasy chorizo. It would have been far far better warm though, and that I truly believe. Overall, this only half lived up to the all encompassing hype. The meat special, though slightly more pricey, was worth every bite and was by far our favorite. Is it worth the long slow trek on the district line? No, not really. If only they had a branch closer to central London; but for now, they do not, and I probably won't make the effort to go there again. There are other places, maybe not as good, but not as far out either. In short, I loved Franco Manca, but hate the district line. I'm sorry.

7fjMUuSqLm7EKr_P4bz81w.text: Truly incredible. Owned by an Italian and an Egyptian who have tried to create the scientifically perfect pizza based on those in Napoli. It really is mindblowing. The base is light and fluffy (although the sourdough is a strange taste if you're not used to it). Burnt spots come as standard. The toppings are impressive. Go for a simple pizza. For dessert the choice is too much: my faves are the tiramisu, affogato (espresso over a scoop of vanilla ice cream) and polenta (fluffy cake made of yoghurt and raspberries drizzled in syrup and with a scoop of yoghurt!).

F8lJM-7aSrPYUqZl6iG73A.text: At Franco Manca you get a great value for your money. I go there once a week, it is sooo good. My dad is Italian.. when he goes to Franco Manca he feels like he is back in Italy.. the food it amazing!

vLthRA5dniQAV8B03Z93VA.text: I have never had a bad time here. I've been a regular with family and friends since the place opened. It quickly became extremely popular and shows no sign of ageing. Even though the staff never stick around too long the place has never been badly managed. It would be nice to see more items on the menu but I also understand that the simplicity is part of the charm. If it changed too much now it would seem out of place.

KkgeeILh90UrTHfR583HuQ.text: Had high expectations for this place and arrived just before our 7.30 booking on a Thursday night to an already extremely busy restaurant.Despite booking we had to wait about 15/20 minutes, although were offered drinks. We declined as were crammed in front entrance due to rain along with a dozen others and thought we would end up spilling not drinking the drinks!Pizzas were good, but not the best I've had. Eat with your hands, it was far too much effort trying to cut my pizza without it ending up on my lap. Servers were lovely but hard to understand at times and some didn't seem to understand English well, which was a bit of a problem!Also, don't bother ordering desserts, just stick to the pizza.

pvn2gpfuOxlMd9_aaUGEKg.text: This pizza is some of the best I've had in London. The tomato sauce is flavoursome (where did they find decent tomatoes in London?!) and the crust has such an amazing texture and delicious flavour from the wood burning oven. Shame about the lacklustre staff letting the place down, but saved by lemon sorbet with a shot of limoncello at the end.

StwCnLSmLD2CBOWlzFvk4w.text: Wonderful place to hace a quick informal meal for an amazing value. The only serve 8 different types of pizza and 6 starters, but all good quality. Price of pizzas goes from 4.50 to 6.95. Definitely not a place for a romantic, relaxed or posh dinner, I'm afraid. Not a lot of ingredients to choose from and the quantity in the pizzas is a bit too little. All the meat is pork, so sorry for the Muslims!

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom. Pizza 5

nvVrPmNBfAs2FNNzYkCVvw.text: The BEST sourdough pizza! They use incredibly fresh and authentically Italian ingredients and meals a so inexpensive. Somewhere you could easily go once a week and not get bored of the menu. Delicious!!

Ym0qnTMAcXB-_H1Vxk73pw.text: Absolutely amazing! This is my favorite pizza in London. The ingredients couldn't taste fresher and the pizza couldn't be executed better. To make matters even more surreal, the best-priced pizza in London by far! Such a bargain.Don't let long queues deter you! The line moves quickly and is more than worth the wait.I'm salivating just writing this review...

oWW-0EpseUCwcq-XdrDIJQ.text: Great pizzas, friendly staff and has managed to maintain their local food feel! It can be  very crowded certain times so make sure you book

Ma9uXcUA96eKPrYXpwKeMQ.text: Consistently great pizza. Simple menu but good ingredients make it all really delicious. Very good value - even though prices have gone up in the last couple of years

FnTui28A3CGbiNli01xvCw.text: Excellent excellent wood burning oven pizza.  I love that they focus on local sourcing and interesting combos--my pizza had some type of boar's bacon and rocket.Service was good, and the place was noisy (and a bit hot).  A bit of a chain-feel, but other than that a good place for a good pie.

XauyzgsgdoaNVjsS8P-Vbw.text: Hallelujah! The perfect light pizza (they are made from sour dough, so much easier to digest) at very reasonable prices. If you haven't tried this place, you are missing out.

AFydTM3Kec_OvPTPYEr5QA.text: Stodgy pizzas on undercooked bases. That's been my experience of Franco Manca Chiswick on the two occasions I've paid a visit. Needless to say I'm shocked after the heavenly pizzas I've enjoyed at Franco Manca's original restaurant in Brixton. The pizzas I had at Chiswick were nowhere near the Brixton ones and comfortably inferior to those from any of the common pizzeria chains.There are some saving graces to Franco Manca's branch in Chiswick. One is the ice cream, which is surprisingly good. I also like the way that scoops are served in individual glasses, allowing the experience to be one akin to an ice cream tasting rather than a straightforward dessert. Another plus is the silky jazz in the background. The service though is a little mixed - sometimes quick, sometimes not so quick.Still, Franco Manca is first and foremost a pizzeria and loudly sells itself on that fact. So I think it most appropriate to rate its Chiswick branch on the quality of their pizzas. 'Meh, I'm still coming to terms with my disappointment', would sum it up.

obnNbznGbvkUkvXYGNIFWQ.text: Dear Mr MancaOne was delighted to finally eat here after all the rave reviews you have been getting.Your staff was superb in their service towards me and my friend and your restaurant was impeccable to touch, not a dirt in sight. I was caught in hypnotic trance as I saw those pleasant pizza other were enjoying, they looked marvellous. I couldn't wait to get stuck in.I ordered a mozzarella, tomato and ham pizza. Mr Manca I must say you haven't got much of a selection, you should consider expanding on that.  Well I'am sad to say this but your pizza didn't blow my taste buds away. The pizza base was rather burnt on the sides, the ham....well the bits of it was just so-so. The tomato's and mozzarella I enjoyed... but the sourdough base did nothing for me, I suppose I like my normal pizza base (maybe you should give people that option of choice between the two). Well maybe I was expecting too much, I mean after all the reviews and even Time out, you can't blame me. I say your pizzas are cost effective though which is good. Mr Manca I will give you another go in the future, but for now Cheerio!Lady Raka

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom

QAmf719XQnwSvTo4MydBqA.text: ah whatever with the wine, the pizzas are just so perfect that this just has to be a five star.And now they do lovely desserts like Tiramisu and unlike Brixton you CAN book here. Except at 7.30 every Friday night - 'cos that's my time.

5BdBECGPsXE9ZUyycIOo3Q.text: It's personal preference isn't it. I prefer my Francos experience to be within walking distance to my flat, to be full of people similar to myself (read: relaxed and not too fussy) and a little more intimate. The Chiswick Francos obviously isn't that. It's a trek to get here. It's a much, much bigger restaurant with a more formal feel, and when we visited on a Saturday lunchtime, full of families with kids. They were everywhere. Screaming, crying, throwing food and cutlery all over the place. (and that's just the parents... wheeeyyyyy)So if you're reading this, and have kids and want some delicious pizza, you can't do better than here. Because the pizza is still as good as the Brixton orginal and there is plenty of space for little Sebastian and Isobel to cause merry hell.That being said, you're less likely to have a long queue here and they do have some additional menu items to try out. I'll say it again though; still my favourite pizza in London. By a country mile.

cYbDbsDSvC2ZslLM46hM9Q.text: Honestly, any place that gives me free limoncello shots for attempting to speak Italian, as well as offering cheap and delicious pizzas deserves a full score. I've here three times in less than a month, always seated and served speedily. The pizzas are delicious ( I always go for the vegetarian or vegetarian house specials), their burrata starter melted in my mouth and their Sangiovese organic wine was worth it despite its tiny cup serving. All that and paying under 30£  for a filling meal for you is definitely worth the full marks.

EGPsN5NOSsmoikiSvE0YAA.text: Simply magic sour-dough pizzas.  They offer 6 on the menu and maybe a couple of specials, starting at £4.50 and going all the way up to £6.80.  Franco Manca started in Brixton Market but have opened this branch in Chiswick, and is something of a legend. Their oven goes to 550°C and the pizzas stay in for under a minute.  All the ingredients are specially sourced: tomatoes from Salerno, cured meats from Brindisa, Gloucester Old Spot pork.  They even get their coffee beans from the best coffee in London: Monmouth.Honestly, I've never tasted pizza this good.  I didn't know pizza *could be* this good.

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom

tzMMd-AZuXagYDyABG596w.text: I was very excited to visit Franco Manca while in London, I did some research before going to London, and by the look of it, it seemed that framco manca would be the closest thing to the wonderful pizza i had in Rome at the famous Baffetto's, I've searched and no one can compare, but this time I was right.Franco Manco has captured the essence of a true italian pizza, fresh, light, flavorful, and very satisfying. the crust is a bubbly, soft, piece of heaven, the toppings are fresh and simple, with a light fresh tomato sauce, all cooked in a wood burning brick oven. That is authenticity at it's best!!  this was our cheapest meal while in London and one of the best as well, so good that I went twice while in town. Next time i'm in London Franco Manca will be my first stop for dinner or lunch.

N73Eh0gzHpznYrjaV7g-uQ.text: One of the best pizzas I have ever eaten, in one of the best value restaurants in all of London.Unfussy, quality toppings and a revolutionary sourdough crust (but a soggy base when I went... sorry, minus a star!) Lovely and well priced red wine. Really friendly staff who were attentive and interested in whether we'd tried the pizzas before and what we thought, and gave us a little background on the restaurant. Also really nice atmosphere for the price.Sort out those soggy bottoms and I'll be back to five star you (well I never thought I'd type that...!)

JieZhNxkX7VJTJspj5BneQ.text: Delicious pizza at a great, affordable price!It was busy on a weeknight, and our table was rather ignored.  I think the waitress was relieved when we were leaving, since she was so busy.  I ordered a standard menu item with anchovies, but the topping is secondary.  The crust is thin, crispy, chewy - just beautifully made.  I could just eat the crust with any topping, really.  Bonus - I couldn't finish the pizza and had it for lunch the next, so it made this visit an extra good deal for me.  Took off a star for the rushed service, and also for the fact that this place feels a bit like a chain/factory, and I was a little disappointed to find out it's a chain.  Still 4 stars, though, because I'd definitely pop in now and again for a well made pizza!!

9v5jN4XLtL5RyhWBjyRFBg.text: I love the Franco Manca in Bloomsbury! If you want good pizza this is the place to go.  Authentic Italian with lovely and fast service!

27xAMe25lH0hkRMPd3NqhQ.text: It's not difficult to make good pizza, but I's difficult to make great pizza. Franco Manca makes great pizza.... at an affordable price! Yes, in London! It really doesn't get any better than that (and is precisely why it deserves 5 stars).We came here on a Monday night and it wasn't full but it was surprisingly buzzing for a late Monday evening.  The actual restaurant was much larger than I expected, and stretches pretty far to the back.  There's also a small outdoor seating area with a few tables.  The service was quick and the pizza was fantastic.  I had the meat special, which was certainly not a let-down! The sourdough base, in my opinion, is what gives Franco Manca pizza the edge on other pizzerias.  The base is always thin and soft, but just firm enough.   The chili oil is also fantastic.  The heat is strong, but just right.  For a casual evening out, I would highly recommend Franco Manca.  I will definitely be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom. Meat Special, so so good!!!

1Tvg4YHd-IDtxYtGSFYf3g.text: I came here for dinner the other night with my husband and 3 of my friends and we had a pretty good experience. I love that they stay open pretty late compared to other restaurants around because my group could only get together later in the night for dinner. The ambiance was casual and relatively modern. The space in the restaurant was a little bit tight and it was very narrow and deep. We grabbed a table in the back corner. It was pretty crowded which was a good sign, but also very loud.Our server was nice and checked up on allergies for our group as we requested. This restaurant is very careful with allergies. We started with one of their special starters of the day, "Buffalo Mozzarella + Langhirano Coppa." It was a plate with thin cold cuts of cured beef with fresh mozzarella, arugula, and tomatoes. I really enjoyed this. I loved the cold cuts and the mozzarella. It tasted so fresh and was a nice little snack before the meal. For my meal, I ordered the pizza with Gloucester old spot ham (home cured), mozzarella, buffalo ricotta, and extra tomato sauce. I really enjoyed my pizza! I really liked the sourdough crust and I liked the fact that the crust was not too thick. I loved the ham and cheeses on my pizza as well. They didn't skimp out on the meat which was good. However, I did want extra tomato sauce on my pizza and I felt that they barely put tomato sauce on it. I still really enjoyed the pizza though!I thought that the prices were also very good. Overall, casual ambiance, friendly and careful staff, great prices, and great food! I would definitely recommend Franco Manca.

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom. Buffalo mozzarella & Languiranno Coppa starter special
Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom. Pizza with Gloucester old spot ham (home cured), mozzarella, buffalo ricotta, and tomato sauce
Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom. Menu

EX8YJuOdjC899lu95PoLHw.text: I could write a long reason for why I'm only giving one star, but it simply comes down to the pizza is less then average. They blind you by creative branding and trending decorating but when you eat the pizza you'll taste it is below average and that's being kind.

6jw39p_lOSlIgwXprdr3yg.text: Apologies now for the long and boringly detailed review, it made me feel better!I had heard a lot of really great stuff about Franco Manca, but the higher you are in my expectations, the further you have to fall!There was only a small queue, which moved pretty quickly so that was fine. I had heard great things about the potato pizza, but unfortunately there wasn't on on the menu so I opted for the vegetarian spacial, with an extra potato topping (offered on the board). Our waiter said he would have to check this with the chef, who sent back the message that it was fine and so it was ordered, along with olives, garlic bread, burata, three other pizzas for my companions and a bottle of wine.The burata and the garlic bread came - no olives. By the time we asked about them we decided it was too late so just scrapped them - but not before our waiter had simultaneously looked confused about our question of the olives, whilst trying to blame the kitchen staff for not sending them over.The burata was absolutely DIVINE! And I am told that the garlic bread was tasty too. And the mild organic white wine was dangerously drinkable :)Time for our pizzas to be served, exciting! But our waiter came and said there was no potato left, even though the chef had okayed it earlier. So I was pressured into the garlic pesto (which was actually nice!), after saying no to the artichokes suggested by one of my dining companions (she had ordered extra for her pizza and was singing their praises! But I wasn't sure). We were promised free Limoncello for the table.Two of our pizzas arrived - all good.Mine arrived - no potato of course, but yes there was the garlic oil... and there were the artichokes I'd said no to. Oh well.And so we waited.And waited.And started eating at the insistence of the last remaining diner waiting on her pizza (coincidentally the one who was excited about artichokes).Eventually we managed to call our waiter over to ask whether the last pizza was coming. Again with the confusion and lack of recognition of the order (even though he had entered into discussion about it at the time), mixed with trying to blame the kitchen, saying they 'drive him crazy'. But, although she tried to say she wasn't even hungry anymore so not to bring the pizza, they brought it over. To their credit, they didn't charge us for it, which helped to rectify the situation.We ordered affogatos for dessert (they were great!), and the restaurant delivered on their promise of free Limoncello for the table. (This went further to rectify the farcical evening!)By the end of the night we had had another bottle of wine and to be honest found the whole thing quite funny. They took the artichokes from my pizza off the bill,so they really did rectify every mistake fully, and the food that we did have was all delicious and lived up to the high standards set by all my friends' previous rave reviews. I am sticking with a 3 for this review just because of the service but I will be returning and I have no doubt that my updated review will result in a higher score!

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom. Affogato

OX0SZKSF6GGJ7hS6QHkgPw.text: After a fun afternoon trip to a new neighborhood in London turned into a hostile commute involving numerous bus diversions and the dreaded "the destination of this bus has changed...", we finally arrive in Chiswick. We enjoyed approximately 20 minutes of fading daylight before the skies opened up and unleashed a torrential downpour. Ducking into a bookstore, we decided to see what the trusty Yelp app had to say about dinner. Behold, Franco Manca. I love it when restaurants cut the bulls*** and just focus on a few things they can do well. This place does pizza, and does it very well. Forget 4 pages of mediocre Italian, Franco Manca gives you just a few starter choices and 4-5 choices of pizza. One size fits all. We ordered a mozz started which was awesome, and said no to the house wine in favor of fresh lemonade. The pizzas were awesome. Cooked to perfection in a woodfired oven, with a delicious bubbly sourdough crust and the perfect amount of toppings. We enjoyed the ham, and also the chorizo. ::kisses tips of fingers::. Delicious!Service was attentive and friendly, and I almost laughed when I saw the bill. I think we walked out spending about £10 a person. If it wasn't so, so far from me I'd be in here all the time. Thank you for the refuge Franco Manca, keep on keeping on!

kdTiDSMOBC06e3rRe2FnKw.text: Yummy sourdough pizza at very reasonable prices. The place lacks atmosphere and the acoustics aren't great so it's very loud, but the pizza really is delicious.

X70A_5Sroye3yxY-IENa7Q.text: These guys do really good pizza, it is no surprise that they are so successful. My luck was in too because they were doing a special Stilton, Wild Mushroom & White Truffle Oil vegetarian pizza, which very much conformed to my tastes!The no logo pale ale that they carry is below average as pale ales go, but is perfectly drinkable at the end of the day. Certainly better than the Peroni you find at most pizza restaurants.Very busy, because they are justifiably popular.

xhEN-3GlTuUFB1ALQwJHUw.text: I often come here and the pizza didn't disappoint once. I'm italian myself so believe me I know what a real pizza should taste like and this is sooo nice! (Not the nicest but very nice) get the number 4!!

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom. Pizza with chorizo (number 6 if I'm not wrong) and number 4 (the besssssst)

QnkF3PoEfRw4Vxf431mNag.text: First time to Franco Manca and was invited by a good friend to enjoy some pizza!  Being that I've had pizza in NY, I wondered how it would compare.This is right up there with NY and Chicago for pizzas.  Thin crust pizza and tasted like it was cooked in a wood burning oven so it gave it that charred crisp while the ingredients were fresh.  I ordered the Chorizo pizza and that was delicious.Small but quaint place to enjoy with friends, order a bottle of Malbec.  Easy selection of pizzas, which means they're focused on quality and not quantity.I would easily go back again and again to try all the other ones but was only in town for several days.  Big Fan!!

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom. Front view

hwqBEpjfy9XRqFXY7w2CyA.text: Delicious pizza, great selection of toppings and solid service. Pizza tends to get soggy on the bottom but it still tastes good, just gets messy.

UH-3VPXlxRohuYPErUpdZA.text: The pizza is indeed very nice and relatively inexpensive. The service however was apathetic and disinterested. It took a long time to be acknowledged by our waiter who seemed to be far more interested in fraternizing with his fellow employees than serving customers. Good food, poor service.

Tqh5ZbUgR0TlV80356-YlA.text: Okie dokie.I revisited Franco Manca nearly two years after I first visited and found the seating has changed... for the better. They have moved most of the picnic tables to the back of the restaurant and placed a sleek row of two-tops in their place. A nice touch as it makes the space feel bigger. The problem with this new seating arrangement is that they did not move the coat hooks which are attached to the wall. The coat hooks are now either behind a chair or so close to the chair belonging to the table next to yours that you don't feel comfortable hanging your coat on said coat hook.Nothing has changed with the rating - still four stars. Also still no change with their menu though you can technically build your own pizza by ordering a pizza (e.g. the cheese, basil, and tomato) and then adding on toppings (where your topping selection are the toppings from the other pre-defined pizzas on the list). I still wish they had pepperoni or even created a menu that was a bit more user friendly. I don't know, something just seems off with the way their menu is laid out.My husband and I had excellent service this time around. Job well done!

FNHNMp3ICdHbOdqRoBkjDg.text: Francos is my favourite pizza chain in London. For £4.50, you can get a massive pizza for yourself which is a price that can't be beaten in this town. They have locations all over and the staff have been great at every one I've been to. It's great for vegan options and we always order the garlic bread to go with the pizzas. Their own beer is something to be tried too!

photos.caption: Photo of Franco Manca - London, United Kingdom

D8alKnE7o3b28lRmCSy5kA.text: For a very long time I couldn't find nice pizza in London until I tried Frnco Manca. Now it's my favourite pizza place. It's as it should be, reasonable prices, very good food, all ingredients from farmers and my favourite sicilian wine. It's good for quick snack or for dinners with friends. Only one thing I would change - knifes, sometimes it's big struggle to cut pizza :)

bBsEFCm_pCd8fhHyOMwbkQ.text: Awesome Italian pizzeria with wood oven and very reasonable prices.Try a Meat special pizza - shown on the black  board - changes every week and is always really good.

XamPROhTGAdJn6nr6VWCew.text: OMG I actually go to visit my brother in Chiswick with the proviso that we will go to Franco Manca. I always go for the chorizo with extra rocket, he always goes for whatever is on special that day. The sourdough is excellent and I feel full and satisfied afterwards. I've also been to the tottenham court road branch and the service is great at both. Really one of my favourite pizza places and generally places to eat in London!

azLwgFnCiDZJKbXY9zEkwg.text: Stopped in here for a quick lunch; and indeed I was not disappointed with the speed at which our food came.In terms of choices; it is quite limited with six options of pizzas but I do bare in mind any alterations can be made. But with extra topping choices; for a pizza place I did find it limited. The first time my husband has asked for onions and they didnt have it. onions. I tried the pizza with the ricotta, courgettes, mozzarella; added chillies and tomato sauce. Really tasty and filling. For the price totally worth it. My husband had the margarita pizza with chillies and He wasnt disappointed. All in all; the kick of why this pizza is so tasty simply comes down to the pizza dough. The toppings etc cannot say I havent had better; but the sourdough base is the kicker here and its evident from the first bite to last. Definitely worth a visit. Great taste. limited options.

4MFZnqY59zuafZTP1UQQWA.text: Tasty, basic and very reasonably priced meal in London with outdoor seating, cheap wine and simple recipe of pizza and greens. Each time I visit Chiswick, I eat here at least once for a craving. First option is vegan with many vegan toppings, too.

arL1W4zTKRIZKe1C0EsInA.text: I love the concept at this restaurant: complete transparency. You can see the pizza being made in front of you if you sit at the front of the restaurant, and there are details  on the origins of all the ingredients on the back of the menus.I ordered a personal pie with British cured ham, mushrooms, mozzarella, and ricotta cheese. The dough was fluffy and charred to perfection. No complaints about any of the ingredients. On each table were two types of olive oil which were perfect for dipping a little of the crust into.The service was quite attentive too; all I had to do was look up and a server was there as soon as he or she finished the task at hand.To top it off, the prices were extremely reasonable.

IwJt6TxMuB4w-szYoBA4BA.text: Nice pizza, but not amazing.I really liked the restaurant and the ambiance. The manager was there even serving tables, that's a nice touch.
